My boyfriend practices diligently and takes Buddhism seriously, which I admire and respect. I came to Buddhism through him, and I feel supported by him in this direction. Which is the problem. I think it's just way too much support! In situations where I feel I'm being pushed into something, I tend to "block up." I know that in this particular matter that's not a good strategy, but even so, I'd like to do things my own way and at my own pace — even if that means doing only 400 prostrations a month. It seems like he's nicer to me only when I do some prostrations, and I have the feeling I'm doing them to please him. That's not a good reason to practice, is it? It's dividing us, and I feel that once this passes, I'll enjoy the prostrations more... hopefully. Is this just the problem of my stubborn ego and should I push myself more, or should my boyfriend ease up? Thank you for your answer and have a lovely day.

Whoever is genuinely interested in Buddhism is primarily interested in the core of this more or less profound psychology — namely the so-called absorptions (jhanas/samadhis). And generally, the entire spiritual teaching is usually explained in such a way that it has neither head nor tail, and a beginner is left with a confused mess out of it. Almost everyone keeps talking to them about various types of yoga, concentration — whether on the spiritual heart, or on the Self, or on nothing. But all of these are vanities always overcome by our vitality, which — let's admit it — sometimes does with us whatever it wants. It determines whether we want something or not. Whether we give something up or not. But in the end this isn't a matter of rational deliberation. That's why it's important for a person to understand yoga not as concentration, but above all as a way of life. That's why we must begin with yogic pre-training. This is divided into YAMA and NIYAMA. The problem of a happy or unhappy life is a problem of feeling. And since from the standpoint of yoga this problem must be solved first, YAMA is prescribed as the first step. YAMA means discipline of feeling. Through it, happiness is literally "manufactured." An angry, biased and unpleasant person would like to throw all of this behind them and simply sit down in some yogic posture and concentrate until they become happy. But it is not possible to arrive at feelings of happiness through concentration alone, nor is it possible to achieve discernment through moral discipline alone, so that consciousness can free itself from the last dregs of ignorance. Everything has its time and sequence. So one needs to observe those "unpleasant" moral commandments. But how? Whenever a person tries to put them into practice, they either forget about them, or despite adhering to them they get agitated, are resentful, greedy, biased, or gossip. So if I am to observe the commandments of morality I must do it ACCOMPANIED by a happy mood, a peaceful mind, trust and optimism. The main tool for this is our WILL, by which we deliberately — and against all circumstances — maintain joy, above all JOY WITHOUT CAUSE (that is, independent of surroundings and people). And the more we hold to this joy, the more we will smooth out potential states of the opposite mood. And our happiness will be COMPLETE. The second step is NIYAMA. It concerns bodily and mental hygiene. A person should attend to their appearance, be attentive in dealings with people so as not to appear eccentric. Show restraint in judgments, not react to any behavior or event spontaneously. And occupy the mind by reading spiritual literature and seeking out company engaged in noble deeds and teachings. Enlightenment and perfect self-knowledge bring a person to the level of a sage, whereas yogic pre-training brings them to the level of an ABSOLUTELY HAPPY person — that is, at the end of moral transubstantiation. What I want to say is that practicing meditation without PREPARATION makes no sense. Every beginner should be aware of that. Otherwise they will be disappointed.

I'm starting to practice and would like to ask about a few things — specifically three. 1) I have a bit of a problem with the theory. So far I've read some books by our lama Ole, but I don't understand some of the concepts — they seem to me not to be explained precisely enough. On the other hand, when I read 'The Great Seal' a second time, I read more between the lines, so it's probably in me somewhere. Intuitively I feel this is my path, but since I'm a bit of a perfectionist, I need things categorized. I think books by other lamas in our lineage would also help me, so I could see the teaching from multiple angles. Could you please recommend some other literature you've had a good experience with? Are you also preparing something like a glossary of terms? 2) On the practical side: I haven't yet received a blessing from Ole and I started meditating on the refuge — is that possible? I looked at the travel schedule and he'll be here sometime in December. He has a public lecture and some kind of triangle course; I'm not sure exactly what happens at those events, but is it possible to receive a blessing there? 3) What is an empowerment? At what stage of preparation is it needed? You can see I'm a bit muddled about all this. Many thanks for the answer.

Thank you so much for your column — it's really, really wonderful. I've been meditating for some time now, though I still have a few doubts about various things. I read that mantras don't work at all when we recite them mechanically without believing in their power. Also, I don't understand how it's possible that so few people are enlightened, given that quite a lot of people practice Buddhism, mainly in Asia, and some have since childhood. A friend of mine was on a natural science expedition in the Himalayas and had the chance to spend some time in Tibet. She said that Tibetans are truly rich within and can experience life more fully than most of us in Europe, but some of them are quite hot-headed, tough, and overly proud — typical mountain folk — and are probably about as far from enlightenment as most other people. :-) And one more question about reincarnation: is it true that a person usually reincarnates in the same or similar places, and usually also with the people they knew in past lives? And how badly do I have to behave to be born as a dog in my next life? :-)) Take care and all the best!

prompt:
Is classical conditioning the same thing as trauma. Please respond with a snarky but true response.
<extra_id_1>Assistant
Absolutely not. Classical conditioning refers to the process by which a neutral stimulus comes to elicit a response through association with a stimulus that always elicits that response. This is a learning process that occurs naturally in humans and other animals. Trauma, on the other hand, refers to an emotional or psychological injury resulting from a deeply disturbing or distressing event. These two concepts are not related.
<extra_id_1>User

The President of the company said, “I don’t understand why you refused to sign until now. What was your problem?”

What is the moral lesson of the story?

A large part of Buddhist teaching and its truths stands or falls on the fact of reincarnation and some kind of higher good that ensures a better next incarnation for those who behave in a certain way. The entire body of knowledge and understanding (with a few interpretive exceptions) tends toward the conclusion that this is simply not the case. In other words: the more we know, the fewer possibilities there are to defend it, and that is deeply troubling. What if all suffering ends at death? Then the idea of karma — and essentially all similar ideas — is hardly defensible. This entire magnificent system of thought rests on a foundation that one simply must take on faith. I consider Buddhism the religion closest to humanity. Yet the Four Noble Truths may very well be only four half-truths. Honza

prompt: Setting aside a number of other things, here is one that stands out. A large part of Buddhist teaching and its truths stands or falls on the fact of reincarnation and some kind of higher good that ensures a better next incarnation for those who behave in a certain way. And unlike other things that can at least be defended by logic, there is no — and probably never has been any — tangible proof of this. The entire body of knowledge and understanding (with a few interpretive exceptions) tends toward the conclusion that this is simply not the case. In other words: the more we know, the fewer possibilities there are to defend it, and that is deeply troubling. Death then ends everything connected with a given being, and the meaning of nirvana — and of all Buddhist striving — falls apart. What if there is no cycle in connection with the 'soul'? What if all suffering ends at death? Then the idea of karma — and essentially all similar ideas — is hardly defensible. This entire magnificent system of thought rests on a foundation that one simply must take on faith. I consider Buddhism the religion closest to humanity. Yet the Four Noble Truths may very well be only four half-truths. Honza

I'd like to know how you handle situations like donating to various causes when it's simply impossible to give to everyone? Sometimes it's enough that I walk through town and I'm glad I have enough left for the bus, because there are so many people asking for contributions — children's homes, beggars, and so on. But when I don't give anything, I feel quite bad about it, because I think that beggars and abused children need the money more than I do — yet I simply don't have enough to give to everyone. I'd also be curious whether Ole has some kind of ordinary day job or whether he dedicates all his time to Kagyu, meditation, and teaching. Thanks a lot for your answer.

Do I exist? The more I search and the more I see, the more the whole world seems like just a game of my own mind. Every person is a part of me, an aspect of my mind — whether you're practitioners or not. The entire universe is me. Billions of my aspects searching for themselves until they unite into one and shine for a moment in awareness, and then dissolve again. Thanks for practicing, because you're a part of me that's moving toward the moment of unity of mind. We exist as a play of energy. And where's the question? Look, I'm not really enjoying this right now and it somehow feels pointless. What if the so-called higher goals I've had in life — like reaching enlightenment — aren't actually worth any more? Because that too is just a momentary state. Somehow I, as the universe/space, am going through a personal crisis and I've forgotten why all of this is happening here in this world. So what do you say from the Buddhist perspective?

Good morning. I'd like to ask about karma in the case of people who are mentally disabled — for example, those born that way. If I've understood correctly, these people are 'working off' bad karma from past lives. But when you look at such a person's situation, their karmic prospects going forward seem truly grim.

A mentally disabled person often has no awareness of the world they're in. They may have no sense of anything happening around them — perhaps just lying restrained in a bed, staring at the ceiling. How are they supposed to 'improve' their karma when no opportunity is given to them to do so? Such a person certainly has no idea what causality even is. It seems to me that this situation is a dead end for them.

Are they destined in the next life to again have a similarly disabled existence — or is experiencing just one such difficult life sufficient as 'punishment'? I also read in earlier posts here that enlightenment can be achieved within a single lifetime, which I don't see as feasible for these people.

Thank you for your answer and take care.

prompt: Recently I squashed a mosquito in my room. I'd had several bites from it the previous night and its buzzing was really getting to me. I did it with the mantra Om *smack* Hung and without anger — I didn't want it to bite anyone else, so I didn't drive it away. Otherwise I try not to harm things and I shoo flies and wasps outside with a mantra. But with the mosquito I genuinely had no motivation... I hope I haven't broken my bond with the lama — or with Lama Ole — by doing this. And what kind of consequence have I brought on myself through killing it? My thought is that at worst it'll come back and bite me twice as much and in more sensitive places... How do you handle these situations yourself? I suppose I should try harder to see the mosquito as a camel rather than a greasy smear, right?

I wanted to ask whether it is safe to work with the fire element — and what defects might arise — before the earth and water elements have been processed. I also have a question regarding the Chinese invasion of Tibet. Apparently this is a karmic punishment, because that land allowed the teachings of the White Dynasty of Kagyu gurus to be lost. This lineage was supposedly last transmitted to Milarepa, and none of the subsequent successors — including the Karmapas — attained this transmission. The spiritual attainments of the current Karmapa are apparently below average. And even though the Dalai Lama has comparatively higher-quality initiations, he too apparently has not reached the level of Avalokiteshvara and is therefore said to be the last Dalai Lama — the previous one still had that transmission. The teachings of the White Dynasty of Kagyu gurus were apparently transferred to Europe according to an old Tibetan prophecy. I wanted to ask whether Lama Ole Nydahl ever spoke about this. I had the honor of attending one meeting with him and was somewhat taken aback when, in response to the question 'What about the Islamists?', he answered: 'Wipe them out.' If that is meant to be his 'sense of humor,' I appreciated it in the same vein as when he told the audience that he no longer has an ego. I would just note that the ego still exists in the state of turiya, which was attained, for example, by Jesus or Francis of Assisi. Thank you for your answer.

I am creating a business with some partners. Let me first describe the business, it involves algorithmic trading of sports on sports exchanges. Initially betfair, but later other exchanges. To do this i need to create a 'listener' to connect directly to the betfair api and receive live packet data from the exchange. This will be used for dual purposes, stored in a database and for live trading. For the live trading, I will create machine learning based models and need to create a robust order management system...this will be a control for the trained models. The models require a lot of data, both exchange data, and state of game data. We will need to buy historic data for this, but the historic data will need to be the same data as we can receive on a point in time basis. Beyond this we will be creating tools, such as simulation tools, back-testing, queries the data and running analytics and live displays of pricing and state of game. The hope here is to set up a tech side of the business where customers will pay for the use of this. Can you come up with both ideas and a business plan for all of the above over the next 6 months. Ideally can you also come up with ideas for monetisation and finally innovative ways I might be able to integrate gpt4 into this business to create compelling content. The language will be python, some technical details I am unclear on, although i know machine learning, so including technical ideas is also welcome.

Lately I've been dreaming that I'm being murdered. I used to have dreams like this before too, but back then I was afraid of death. Now I dream that when someone kills me, only my body dies, and my soul somehow steps out of the body and watches — watches my body and the killer, who thinks he's killed me but in reality I'm not dead. These dreams are so intense that I'm afraid to go to sleep. Could it be because I meditate before bed? So far I'm only doing the short Refuge, Prostrations — I haven't done the Phowa yet. P.S. I read somewhere that sometimes when you meditate, your mind cleanses itself of negative things during sleep — but how will I know when I've cleared everything negative, that there's nothing left to cleanse?

After reading several questions and answers here, one question comes to me. There are many paths of spiritual development and many reasons why people choose to walk them. I understand — he's someone who is further along and is therefore able to pass on and teach what he has gone through. I just hope it's not about clinging to him. We are him and he is us — so why then the constant reference? Thanks, Tereza

But sharing is a powerful support. Is that why there's always a reference back to Lama Ole? I understand — he's someone who is further along and is therefore able to pass on and teach what he has gone through. I just hope it's not about clinging to him. We are him and he is us — so why then the constant reference? Thanks, Tereza

I'm studying dharma quite a lot now so tons of questions are arising. 1) What is the difference between faith and trust? Somehow that's not clear to me... and it seems to me it's basically the same - I can't verify either right now... Regarding karma - situation: let's say I see a situation where an older person is picking on a younger one and wants to beat them... it's both their karma (one is sowing bad karma and the other is clearing it). Now I enter that situation and try to help the younger one and deflect the attack. Doesn't that create new karma where they'll sometime help me? Or is the difference that I can choose whether to intervene in that situation and that's where compassion lies... whereas they can't change that situation, so that's their karma? And what happens to their karma - one was supposed by karma to beat the other and I prevented it - does that mean when I intervened the circle was broken, or will they resolve it in another situation?

prompt: Right now I'm doing the preparatory meditation for Phowa (I'm about two-thirds of the way through) and during the meditation, doubts about what I'm doing in that moment have started appearing, which pulls me away from the meditation. I try to remind myself that the path is the goal and who I'm doing it for (not for myself) — but it doesn't always work, and I lose what I'm not sure how to name properly — a certain openness and awareness of the pure land. When that happens I just let it be and focus only on reciting the mantra. Is mantra recitation alone sufficient? Am I doing the meditation incorrectly when doubts arise? Thank you in advance for the advice. — Riso

What am I doing wrong? My wife and I are fighting all the time. What can I do? We don't agree on anything and she usually jumps to conclusions, which are usually wrong on how I feel. She is very family-oriented while all of my family left me on my butt, abused, ignored and messed up with me mentally. I'm not a family-oriented person. I only have two people in my life - my best friend and my wife.    My mother forced my father out of my life so I do not know who he really is. We've gotten in contact but he just makes comments on how much I look like her when in fact I look more like him. This makes me mad because I don't want to look like my mother. I hate her. All that she did was bring me down and make me homeless, which she was successful at. I need guidance in my life. I don't want to lose my wife but we need to have a space because we usually hit each other and it's not healthy. I'm dying to make our relationship healthy. I've never wanted anything more than this. Please help me. I need your advice.

prompt: I have a somewhat personal question for you. You've been practicing for quite a few years now and you've certainly encountered spiritual pride. How did it show up in you? I've only been practicing for a few months, but my ego is so inflated that I think I'm absolutely wonderful, brilliant, and amazing — and also much wiser than other people, which on one hand is probably partly true, but on the other hand is a terrible lie. A wise person can never be sad, yet I'm sad every day for at least five minutes, sometimes twenty. Take care, and I'm throwing you a life ring so you don't drown in the sea of your magnificent patience in answering my crazy questions.

I want to ask... it's not only about Buddhism. Sometimes I feel a lump in my throat, a kind of heaviness — quite an unpleasant tension, even a feeling of nausea. I felt it when Ole was in Brno, at the Medicine Buddha initiation. Right now I'm not meditating because I don't yet know where to begin. I'm a bit lost. And I don't want to surrender myself to just anything — and that's probably also a bad attitude, right? Another question that just came to me: what do you think about creation? Who came up with how to live in this world and not get lost? I suppose the time will come and I'll know when to meditate. Meditating doesn't feel right to me now — it's like it's not really ME. Sorry for being so direct. It's exhausting. Right now I'm looking into homeopathy... or not? I'll probably try it and somehow try to sort myself out — coming out of some teenage-years substance use. It's been a few years now, but fine. About the nausea — I feel it from people too, not just from Buddhist events and so on. Could it be some kind of vibration that I just can't handle? Maybe it's different things. And the brain is like mud sometimes... I don't know. I'm an actor — but only up to a point — that's just to give an image of my self. But the pictures of Buddhas from the blessing do feel good to me. Could you give me some advice? Thanks. Take care.

I mostly browse this site rather than practice Diamond Way or anything else, but reading the questions I was reminded of an old one of my own. I tried to practice the 'Salutation to the Moon' with commentary. While I was reading the description of the positions and movements from a book, it worked — I repeated them following the text. But the text contained anthropomorphic remarks, and that not only slowed me down but created a kind of resistance in me. I didn't want to offer a cup to the Moon, though I was willing to extend my hand (without personal imagery). Is it simply imagination that I'm rejecting? I want an impersonal approach, free from the imagery presented to the reader — with good intentions, I'm sure — as though the Moon were a being? (I'm not saying it couldn't be, but I don't want to engage with it in that way.) So I never learned the Moon Salutation and don't use it.

My girlfriend and I have been together for 36 months, and we have a shared problem with her mother. She's terribly autocratic and needs to have my girlfriend under constant control, even though she's 23. I'm 26, and it's really getting on our nerves. Sometimes it seems to me that the mother's love for her is terribly conditional — 'I'll love you if you're constantly working, preparing for school exams, and not going out to have fun like I do' — those are her frequent words. Whenever my girlfriend and I go out together for some fun, there's always a million comments about it, sometimes some emotional manipulation, and so on. I recently found out that her mother has even become allergic to me, which wasn't always the case before. My girlfriend and I broke up for six months and then got back together, and her mother is against it. In the past her mother treated me very nicely — she helped me with everything, did my laundry, does my taxes, etc. Now that's somehow disappeared. I'm a regular practitioner, my girlfriend likes to mantra and wants to start formal practice. I hope meditation will prevent her from becoming like her mother in the future — I wouldn't want someone like that next to me. We know what we're going to do with ourselves, but what about her mother? I wouldn't want her head even for free. But at her core, her mother is a good person — she's just terribly frightened. What would you advise us?

So I've been trying to practice for about a year (prostrations, three lights), sometimes better, sometimes worse. Unfortunately I increasingly feel that if we practice only as laypeople — spending 8 hours a day at work (almost the entire day) and dealing with ordinary everyday matters — we keep our minds too occupied with these things and are constantly pushed to think and function in the "old grooves." It seems to me that just morning and evening meditation and the occasional mantra during the day can't bring us to liberation or enlightenment, and that frustrates me considerably. I believe that all successful accomplishers devoted themselves to practice intensively as monastics or yogis. If that's not the case, do you personally know anyone who practices in the lay manner of a working person and has achieved liberation or enlightenment? I'd be very curious to know whether anyone like that even exists, or whether we should look forward to reaching that level sometime in future lives. Thanks for the answer, take care.

If, for example, a Buddhist is at such a level that after death they reach complete enlightenment — dissolve into light, into space — I understand it so that for them there is no longer any self, no world of illusions, no Buddhism. What then — or what energy — sends them back into the impermanent world? Or do they just 'peek' into that boundless space and then decide for themselves? I can imagine that in that clear, open, boundless space, duality is unnecessary, that everything is one. Sometimes that thought gives me an amazing feeling, and other times I feel only emptiness, boredom, pointlessness. Now that I read this back to myself, I see myself crouching at the foot of the mountain, asking what the view is like from the top, how you get back down, and thinking about what else I should ask. So I'm getting up and climbing. But even so, I'd be glad if you'd write something about this. Thanks.

prompt:
I've been thinking about something concerning disturbing emotions. Isn't desire the primary disturbing emotion? When I desire something and don't have it, I get angry; when someone else has it, I feel envy; when I have what I desired, I become attached to it, proud, and greedy. What do you think?

What also somewhat holds back my development is the fact that when I practice and the disturbing emotions begin to dissolve — so does desire. And yet desire can drive people forward, help them achieve goals. I can desire to reach enlightenment — that too is desire. Or I might desire to be wealthy so I can help others. Is that specifically bad, and can it be labeled a disturbing emotion?

For example when I run a business, desire is very necessary — you need to be driven and not stop at anything. I don't particularly need the money myself; I want to be wealthy for my partner, for my children, for the other beings I can help that way, since money moves the world.

I've probably mixed several questions into one. I hope it's comprehensible. Thank you and all the best to you.

How does one learn practical thinking and realism? Is there some meditation for it? The thing is I tend to make decisions that have long-term impact and after a while I realize those plans are unrealistic and it can't be reversed, or only with difficulty. Right now I made one such decision about school and I really doubt it was right. The bad thing is it's several in a row already... I must add that when I look at myself a year ago when I started practicing, I see someone who imagines war as a game - simply crazy naivety :-)

Since I was little, I've been afraid of death. Lately I've been reading lots of books about the soul, out-of-body experiences, past lives, etc. Most authors agree that the soul's goal is to become "perfect" and merge with God. I don't know if achieving God-consciousness (Buddha-consciousness) is permanent and unchanging. I also read that the universe expands and collapses and with it the absolute consciousness. So consciousness would constantly move in circles from unconsciousness to consciousness, etc. I don't know where the truth is and how to find it. I often get depressed about this. Could you please give me some advice?

I started practicing Buddhism only recently and I'd like to ask about one thing. How do you explain to colleagues at work, friends, and acquaintances what Buddhism is? Especially when they ask what those strings I'm wearing on my wrist are, what the beads are for, why I usually don't have time on Monday evenings (lecture), etc. It's a problem for me with people who I feel look down on it, consider it a cult, and think people who practice and meditate are crazy. Most of all, it's a problem explaining it to my parents. I know they belong to the group that would consider me a weirdo. I don't care much what people think of me, but with parents it's different. I just don't know how to explain it to them so they'd understand it's nothing bad.

I attended a retreat in Těnovice in 2008 as a complete beginner. Since then I've gradually come to realize how much the Path has opened up for me and how much I received there. I just arrived at your new website and it's really good — lots of information, a great overview, simply excellent. And like many others, I have a question. My girlfriend and I are both interested in Buddhism and Tibet. We practice Buddhism — for example, the mantra Om Mani Pame Hung, which is my favorite and I can never resist it; it's simply wonderful and I recite it quite often. Besides that, we read various Buddhist books and magazines, and we've visited the center a few times — first at the Školská location and a few times at Vinohrady. As I mentioned, we practice, but it's fair to say we're beginners. We'd like to start our Buddhist path more intensively and fully. So we want to ask where, and especially with whom, we could take refuge, and where to find a teacher who could guide us afterward. After taking refuge, we'd like to prepare for phowa and then begin ngondro. Is this the right approach? Thank you, and we look forward to your answer. We wish you lots of positive and creative energy and a clear mind. David and Katka

I'd like to ask about something that caught my attention. I'll say upfront that I'm not a Buddhist, but my brother is and we occasionally discuss various topics. Yesterday I looked at your website for the first time and happened to read the introduction — the key terms — and I was struck by this statement: "What is the significance of the teacher? The popular Western notion of achieving enlightenment alone cannot compare to the rapid success of complete practice with a teacher or in a group. Although achieving enlightenment alone sounds very appealing to the modern person who feels master of their own life, it presents too many pitfalls. Understanding the mind is far more treacherous than studying external phenomena, and enemies in the form of pride and displeasure always lurk, capable of derailing a given individual's development. The highest level of teaching cannot be properly understood or maintained without a teacher. If the communication that neutralizes pride, sentimentality and superficiality is absent, a person can become lonely or useless in everyday life. The lama uses methods to develop the potential of his students, enabling them to push through layers of habitual behavior. The lama's role is to make his students independent, compassionate and strong. At the highest level he allows his students to enter the fearless mirror-hall of his mind. Once they then discover that they share the same nature, there is nothing left to find out." I couldn't understand from what position you claim that something cannot compare to something else. My brother wasn't able to answer me, which is why I'm asking here. I agree that there are many pitfalls — such is life. I don't want to separate life from spiritual life, but how do you know that progress will be faster with a teacher or in a group? I don't want to analyze the very notion of progress here, which I also consider misguided — that's for a longer discussion. How do you know it's not possible to maintain the final state without a teacher? Again I don't want to discuss what maintaining a final state means since I don't quite understand it, but what interests me is: where does your certainty come from that what you believe is good, and that what you believe should be achieved, is somehow better with a teacher? Who can claim this? And please don't say an enlightened person, because then that person couldn't view things in an enlightened way if they made such a claim — it would be asserting that something is better than something else, which is dualism, isn't it? You know, if it said that the meaning of a teacher is only to advise when I want to be guided, nothing could be objected to, but this invites debate. Maybe you'll object that your Buddhist experience is such, but what if other experiences are completely different? And wasn't the Buddha himself an example of the denial of the above? He didn't need a teacher — was he somehow exceptional? My view is that he was not. I'll add that I'm not a follower of any teaching. Thanks in advance for the response.

I'd like to ask about something that caught my attention. I'll say upfront that I'm not a Buddhist, but my brother is and we occasionally discuss various topics. Yesterday I looked at your website for the first time and happened to read the introduction — the key terms — and I was struck by this statement: "What is the significance of the teacher? The popular Western notion of achieving enlightenment alone cannot compare to the rapid success of complete practice with a teacher or in a group. Although achieving enlightenment alone sounds very appealing to the modern person who feels master of their own life, it presents too many pitfalls. Understanding the mind is far more treacherous than studying external phenomena, and enemies in the form of pride and displeasure always lurk, capable of derailing a given individual's development. The highest level of teaching cannot be properly understood or maintained without a teacher. If the communication that neutralizes pride, sentimentality and superficiality is absent, a person can become lonely or useless in everyday life. The lama uses methods to develop the potential of his students, enabling them to push through layers of habitual behavior. The lama's role is to make his students independent, compassionate and strong. At the highest level he allows his students to enter the fearless mirror-hall of his mind. Once they then discover that they share the same nature, there is nothing left to find out." I couldn't understand from what position you claim that something cannot compare to something else. My brother wasn't able to answer me, which is why I'm asking here. I agree that there are many pitfalls — such is life. I don't want to separate life from spiritual life, but how do you know that progress will be faster with a teacher or in a group? I don't want to analyze the very notion of progress here, which I also consider misguided — that's for a longer discussion. How do you know it's not possible to maintain the final state without a teacher? Again I don't want to discuss what maintaining a final state means since I don't quite understand it, but what interests me is: where does your certainty come from that what you believe is good, and that what you believe should be achieved, is somehow better with a teacher? Who can claim this? And please don't say an enlightened person, because then that person couldn't view things in an enlightened way if they made such a claim — it would be asserting that something is better than something else, which is dualism, isn't it? Maybe you'll object that your Buddhist experience is such, but what if other experiences are completely different? And wasn't the Buddha himself an example of the denial of the above? About my trip to Morroco. My name is Jabir.
 i arrive 7AM april 6, then a 3-4 hour trip to fez to my dad's house in fez, so i assume april 6-7 is going to be fez minimum
 i come back april 17 so april 16-17 will be casablanca
 the rest of the days are still up in the air.
 Can you give me some recommendations for my trip?
<extra_id_1>Assistant
Jabir, here are my recommendations:
 

 • For April 6-7, I recommend staying in Fez and exploring the medina, which is the old city. The medina is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and it’s very beautiful and interesting. There are many interesting sights to see there, such as the Fez Medina, the Bab Boujloud, and the Dar Batha Museum. You can also visit the medina’s many colorful markets, which sell everything from spices to carpets. It’s a great way to get a feel for the city.
 

 • For April 16-17, I recommend staying in Casablanca and visiting the city’s many historic sights, such as the Casablanca Cathedral and the Anfa Place. You can also visit the Casablanca medina, which is smaller than the Fez medina but still very interesting. There are also many interesting museums in Casablanca, such as the Museum of Casablanca and the Daru-El-Bacha Museum. You can also visit the city’s many beautiful parks, such as the Parc de la Ligue Arabe and the Parc du 33e Anniversaire.
<extra_id_1>User
What should I do on the other days? Thanks
<extra_id_1>Assistant
On the other days of your trip, I recommend exploring the rest of Morroco. You can visit the imperial cities of Rabat and Meknes, the blue city of Chefchaouen, the desert town of Merzouga, and many other interesting places. You can also explore the countryside, which is very beautiful and has many interesting natural sights, such as the Ifrane National Park and the Dades Valley. It’s a great way to experience the country.

prompt: One thing strikes me as quite strange. If the killing of animals in slaughterhouses is the result of the karma of the butcher and the animal, I'd like to know how it's possible that one being — the butcher — has so many unresolved karmic connections with thousands upon thousands of others, while the vast majority of us, who intentionally kill almost nothing in our lives, don't. Another thing — I understand that Buddhism tolerates killing for meat, but I can't understand how a Buddhist can approve of the utterly appalling conditions in which billions, perhaps tens of billions, of animals live every day. You often compare the killing of wild animals in a field — who die because of the grain we eat — with the killing of pigs in factory farms. But these two things are not, have never been, and never will be comparable. The animal in the field has freedom and will most likely die because of its own failure to avoid the combine harvester. The pig in a factory farm, on the other hand, lives for months in terrible, cramped, and stressful conditions and is then transported to slaughter, which is often quite painful. And this happens to tens of thousands of animals every single day. Please, in the future, don't compare the death of wild animals with the death of 'modern-day slaves.' By the way — have you ever visited a factory farm or a slaughterhouse, Radek? I don't want to moralize here about killing itself, but rather about the way of life to which we force billions upon billions of living creatures every year. That is a problem, and every Buddhist should recognize it. Eating meat from organic farms, where there are fairly strict conditions for both rearing and slaughter, I approve of completely. Factory farms are something diametrically different — and that's something you should be aware of, if only for the sake of your own personal development.

And this happens to tens of thousands of animals every single day. Please, in the future, don't compare the death of wild animals with the death of 'modern-day slaves.' By the way — have you ever visited a factory farm or a slaughterhouse, Radek? I don't want to moralize here about killing itself, but rather about the way of life to which we force billions upon billions of living creatures every year. That is a problem, and every Buddhist should recognize it. Eating meat from organic farms, where there are fairly strict conditions for both rearing and slaughter, I approve of completely. Factory farms are something diametrically different — and that's something you should be aware of, if only for the sake of your own personal development.

One thing strikes me as quite strange. If the killing of animals in slaughterhouses is the result of the karma of the butcher and the animal, I'd like to know how it's possible that one being — the butcher — has so many unresolved karmic connections with thousands upon thousands of others, while the vast majority of us, who intentionally kill almost nothing in our lives, don't. Another thing — I understand that Buddhism tolerates killing for meat, but I can't understand how a Buddhist can approve of the utterly appalling conditions in which billions, perhaps tens of billions, of animals live every day. You often compare the killing of wild animals in a field — who die because of the grain we eat — with the killing of pigs in factory farms. But these two things are not, have never been, and never will be comparable. The animal in the field has freedom and will most likely die because of its own failure to avoid the combine harvester. The pig in a factory farm, on the other hand, lives for months in terrible, cramped, and stressful conditions and is then transported to slaughter, which is often quite painful. And this happens to tens of thousands of animals every single day. Please, in the future, don't compare the death of wild animals with the death of 'modern-day slaves.' By the way — have you ever visited a factory farm or a slaughterhouse, Radek? I don't want to moralize here about killing itself, but rather about the way of life to which we force billions upon billions of living creatures every year. That is a problem, and every Buddhist should recognize it. Eating meat from organic farms, where there are fairly strict conditions for both rearing and slaughter, I approve of completely. Factory farms are something diametrically different — and that's something you should be aware of, if only for the sake of your own personal development.

Bioinformatics is a field that combines biology, computer science, and information technology to analyze and interpret biological data. One of the key challenges in bioinformatics is the management and analysis of large datasets, such as those generated by genome sequencing projects. Bioinformatics tools can be used to identify patterns in these datasets, which can then be used to make predictions about the function of genes and proteins. How does the challenge of managing large datasets impact the field of bioinformatics?
A. It has led to a decrease in the use of bioinformatics tools.
B. It has driven the development of new algorithms and software tools.
C. It has made bioinformatics a less relevant field in biology.
D. It has resulted in a decrease in the amount of data being generated in biology.

First of all, I'm glad these pages work properly in my browser (Firefox) and are really well done both in content and design. I already wrote a personal question, but then something in a text I read on lama-ole-nydahl.cz caught my attention — it says: 'All the people who helped organize the talk will go out for a beer together.' That really confuses me... Buddhists don't touch or consume alcohol, do they? Maybe I misunderstood it, or maybe it's meant more symbolically and they just have one or two so it doesn't mess them up too badly? And another thing: in my life I smoked quite a bit of weed, and now more for fun about once a month — it's more of a break from work and worries, so I'm not an addict anymore, and it actually amused me that I can talk about quitting with others who also smoked — apparently there are quite a few of them. Lama Ole Nydahl himself apparently smoked too. And a final question: I'm gay and I've already read that this really isn't a problem. But now I've met a guy who attracts me body and mind. He identifies with the Jewish faith; at his school they studied all religions and philosophies including Buddhism, and when I asked him whether he would mind me wanting to study Diamond Way Buddhism he replied: 'Well, the thing is I know quite a bit about it and I'm a little afraid of it... we covered it at university, including the practical implications...' That's all he said. What should I make of this? I'm afraid it bothers him. I can't figure it out. So I'm thinking I've probably finally found the path to a contented life, and I'll certainly visit the Prague center soon. I look forward to it.

Question: Use the following email and categorize the colors mentioned into cool, neutral, and warm colors. Organize the colors in alphabetical order.

Reference text: Subject: Interior Design Color Palette for Our New Office Space

Dear Team,

As we prepare to move into our new office space, it's time to start thinking about the interior design and color scheme that will define our workspace. Let's create a vibrant yet harmonious environment that inspires creativity and productivity. Here are some color suggestions to consider for our office decor:
* For the main meeting area, we could use a calming shade of green to promote a sense of tranquility and openness.
* In the workstations, we might opt for a sophisticated gray to create a professional yet modern ambiance.
* To add a pop of energy and warmth to communal areas like the break room, a cheerful yellow accent wall could be a great choice.
* In the executive offices, we could use a deep blue to convey a sense of authority and elegance.
* For the reception area, a welcoming shade of orange could create a friendly and inviting first impression.
Let's aim for a cohesive color palette that reflects our company culture and values. We will also need to consider designs for Conference Room 1, Conference Room 2, and Conference Room 3. Feel free to share your ideas and preferences as we work together to design our new office space.

Best regards,
Jaime Ekman

I have experienced cycles of depression for the past four years, and it hits me harder every time it comes back. This past time, it was extremely debilitating, so I went on Wellbutrin. I could feel the effects of the medicine after the first week. A month and a half later, I decided that my depression was being caused by my own unwillingness to move forward and address my behaviors and thoughts that were keeping me in a place of despair. I became worried that the medicine was making me complacent and prohibiting me from working out what I needed to in my life to bring back true fulfillment. I stopped taking it a month ago and feel okay; a lot of the anxiety it was paired with has gone away. However, I still don't feel my sense of self has been completely regained, and I have days where I feel a zombie-like haze of having no interests or the ability to fully concentrate on anything. Is it better to continue letting time and good habits work out the remaining depression or should I go back on the medicine?

I'm studying the dharma quite a lot lately and questions keep arising by the ton. 1. What's the difference between faith and trust? It's not really clear to me... they seem basically the same — neither can be verified right now from the present situation, so the underlying foundation is the same... On the topic of karma — situation: let's say I see a situation where an older person is picking on someone younger and wants to rough them up. Is this both of their karma — one is sowing bad karma and the other is purifying it? Now I step into the situation and try to help the younger person and deflect the attack. 2. Isn't it again my karma that I somehow "owe" something to the younger person, which is why I'm helping him? 3. Does new karma arise from this, where he will at some point help me? Or is the difference that I can choose whether to intervene in the situation — and that's where compassion comes in — whereas they couldn't change their situation, which is why it's their karma? 4. And what happens to their karma? The one was karmically meant to rough up the other, and I disrupted it — does that mean that by stepping in I broke the cycle, or will they work it out again in another situation? Thanks! I'd like to be clear on this.

I read Trungpa Rinpoche's book "Cutting Through Spiritual Materialism." The whole book seems powerful and convincing. I realized I'm a spiritual materialist through and through. I've completed prostrations, been to phowa, collect a lot of information about dharma. A lot of joy and awareness emerges from practice. Of course, intellectually I understand that personal satisfaction is composed of how well those around me are doing, but I don't really feel it (except during heightened awareness from meditation). I'm drawn inward instead of being useful to people around me. Why don't we address the problem of spiritual materialism? Is something fundamentally wrong, or will further practice break this "collector of happiness, power, intuition, knowledge about dharma and similar circus effects" mindset?

prompt: Thanks for your energy and your answers. Buddhism is great — I was very enthusiastic when I encountered it. I've been doing prostrations and I'm halfway through. Ole is coming to Bratislava soon, so I'm really looking forward to it. Okay, now my problem. I'm cold as a stone. I don't notice other people's feelings, and when I do catch a glimpse of them, I get scared. Or it just feeds the ego and I walk around with my nose in the air thinking I'm somehow above it all. I have trouble noticing my own feelings and trouble expressing them (even writing this is a struggle for me). I don't have a girlfriend even though I don't look bad, but I have trouble getting close to someone, or letting anyone close to me, even though I'd very much like to. And basically no one knows how I really feel. I think this is connected to my family too. My mother has been divorced twice and drinks. She has good periods when she's not drinking, but I can't find my way to her — I'm probably afraid of being disappointed again. Sometimes when I get what feels like a slap from the protectors, I realize what shape I'm really in. The illusion that everything is fine collapses and self-blame and fault-finding set in. A pretty nice zoo, reading this now. :) Please, what should I do to move forward somehow? Especially the emotional coldness, and the relationship with my mother. Thank you.

Is it true that when a person reaches enlightenment, they love everyone equally and don't prefer anyone? Does that mean my partner will mean exactly the same to me as any other being? I've heard that some people, after practicing for a while, no longer feel such a need to hold on to their partner — that they may even love them more, yet would be okay if they left.

Why I'm writing this — I'm simply not convinced I want that. I think I'd rather merge with one person (and of course also feel compassion and love for others) than to love everyone equally and at the same time feel nothing more for anyone in particular.

The 17th Karmapa is enlightened — do his parents and friends mean the same to him as, say, I would? Or does he still love some people more?

I've been to the center and would like to start practicing, but I don't want to lose the immense love I feel for my partner (it's mutual, by the way). I feel as though I've found my kindred spirit. I'd like to grow together with him and stay with him always. I think I may have a problem with motivation, attachment, and confusion. Can you advise me? A brief answer is enough — thanks so much.

Can you please summarize this article into 3 bullet points? Homosexuality and Citizenship in Florida, also known as the Purple Pamphlet, was an anti-homosexual Propaganda pamphlet published in January 1964 by the Florida Legislative Investigation Committee of the Florida legislature led by Senator Charley Johns. The booklet contained several pornographic images and a glossary of terminology used in the gay community. It was sold for 25 cents a copy, with a discount for bulk orders of 100 copies or more.[1]

The Johns Committee had for several years conducted a witch hunt for homosexuals in public schools, universities, and state government agencies, believing they were part of a Communist strategy to "subvert the American way of life by controlling academic institutions and by corrupting the nation's moral fiber." By publishing its findings, the Committee hoped to persuade the Legislature to enact comprehensive anti-homosexual legislation, and to "shock Floridians into accepting its program."[1]

My husband had an emotional affair with his ex-wife in November. She invited him to dinner, alone, with their daughter. I wasn’t aware of this until after 11pm when I asked where he was. He had been drinking, and I told him not to come home that night. The next morning, we talked about going to counseling. He went out that night with friends and said his ex-wife wasn't going. I found out in April that she did go. I gave him the chance to get everything out in the open. I found out that he stayed that second night with her. I asked if they slept in the same bed, and he said yes, both nights. His daughter wasn't there the second night. He claims they didn't have sex, but what else should I think?

prompt: I can't help adding a bit of work for you. But maybe it'll help other readers too. I apologize in advance for the volume of what follows: 1) Anger is a serious disturbing emotion. If we can't avoid it, we cause ourselves problems. Mahakala doesn't quite fit into that for me. Why can he be wrathful and that's okay? Especially in his position? It makes me think: preaching water while drinking wine? What exactly does wrathful compassion mean? Or compassionate wrath? Is it something like: when the path of non-violent guidance of an aggressor unfortunately doesn't work, it's okay to, say, mentally deliver that kick in the rear (as you so beautifully wrote somewhere), and if my wrathful action was purely purposefully compassionate, under full control of an alert mind free from negative emotions or self-satisfaction, will it also be without karmic consequences? Does it work something like that — if anyone can actually manage it? 2) I've always looked with some distrust at promises of quick and easy success. For example, many investment companies proclaimed the highest and fastest returns on clients' deposits — and look how that turned out. I'm sorry for the comparison, but as above, so below. Or: if you want to improve your living situation and decide to get a house, you either build it yourself by the sweat of your brow, or you earn money by the sweat of your brow some other way and buy the house with it, or you get ferried into the clean land of a new house right away — but then you have to sign a mortgage and toil twice as long by the sweat of your brow to pay back the price plus interest. For example, I read the story of a person whose guru helped them achieve certain supernatural abilities unusually quickly. But their state was rather unstable. They lacked the experience of their own effort — weak willpower, insufficient control of disturbing emotions. They couldn't handle it and fell back into the mud, from which they had to struggle through much suffering over many lives before they reached the level they were at before the fall again. But in that state of perfect mind and abilities — regained through such hard work — they remained utterly unshakeable and stable, thanks to the irreplaceable experience of their own efforts. Isn't Phowa, for example, by chance on a mortgage, or on a lease with interest? And how can we verify that the pure land of Buddha Amitabha is really the best thing that can happen to us after death? Sometimes I feel a longing for Phowa and believe that's fine; other times I have strong doubts and think I might be quite naive and gullible. This is something of a weak spot for me, but otherwise the teachings and worldview of Diamond Way simply, in plain terms, suit me. 3) I'd also be interested in your opinion — the Buddhist interpretation of how a person ends up with, for example, such joys as depression, psychosis, or sexual deviation. Gays and lesbians are relatively okay, but what about pedophiles or sadists? They must have hell on earth. If they don't want to create heavy karma, they always have to choose some substitute behavior and never get what they'd most like. Connected with that, it also occurs to me: if negative thoughts and emotions are harmful, what then about nurtured deviant thoughts, imaginings and emotions? 4) You wrote that certain foods close energy centers. What exactly does that mean and what are the consequences? And what foods, conversely, open energy centers? Wishing you lots of strength and patience with people like me — and mainly thank you for making this possible!

I'll try to express myself precisely, or at least sketch out the topic. I'm interested in how it all works with collective mind and collective dream. If mind produces itself — and therefore self and object are one — what then is another being? In the case of achieving enlightenment, isn't the other being also a unity? Why did the mind divide and enter into so many beings? How is it that when one being achieves enlightenment, it doesn't take the others with it, if we are one and the same mind? I'm confused about this — I can't quite get my head around it. I'm not asking about whether it's me or you, but rather: if someone achieves enlightenment, they see how the mind still keeps tormenting itself — and that's strange, isn't it (they have compassion), since they've been liberated — but what exactly have they been liberated from? Their own mind, or the mind as a whole? The dream hasn't actually disappeared and can't really disappear, because even if someone liberates-realizes the mind, the same mistake gets started up again somewhere else — and then all that effort somehow loses its meaning. I also don't quite understand that I'm writing to you, and you are mind, and we're writing to each other within a mind that we ourselves produced. Are you a genuinely independent entity of mind — meaning there is a free mind called You and a free mind called Me? Or are we both one? I don't know. (Not to mention enlightened or near-enlightened beings — those are beings you can't even really write to.) If you tell me I'm writing to myself, I'll probably light up. I hope you can make something of all this — thanks for the answer, take care. Lukas
